Seeking and constructing a suitable p-n heterojunction photoelectrode system is crucial for improving the efficiency of photogenerated electron-hole separation. Herein, the WO3/Cu2O heterostructure was successfully constructed on tungsten mesh using a two-step method. The photoelectrochemical (PEC) properties of the photoanodes loaded with different amounts of Cu2O were investigated by controlling the electrodeposition time. The photocurrent density of the heterojunction with the 60 s electrodeposition time is the highest, reaching 1.47 mA cm−2 at 1.23 V vs. RHE, which is three times that of WO3 nanosheets (0.45 mA cm−2) grown in situ on tungsten mesh. The improved PEC performance is attributed to the wider light absorption spectrum, enhanced photogenerated carrier transfer efficiency and suppressed electron-hole recombination probability. This study indicates that the WO3/Cu2O heterojunction structure grown and constructed in-situ on tungsten mesh has exciting potential for application in efficiency PEC water separation devices. Moreover, it also provides a feasible approach for designing heterostructure systems adapted to complex environments on different substrates to improve PEC efficiency. Graphical abstract The designed and prepared WO3/Cu2O heterojunction structure improves the slow charge transport dynamics of WO3 by forming built-in electric field, achieving efficient light absorption and charge separation. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Tungsten mesh WO3 Cu2O p-n heterojunction PEC Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction The fossil resources widely used by humans currently belong to primary energy, which generates a large number of pollutants during consumption, causing serious impacts on the ecological environment [1,2]. Exploration and developing clean, renewable new energy have become an urgent need for human society [3,4]. The research on photoelectrochemical (PEC) decomposition of water for hydrogen production has received wide attention and rapid development. In this process, semiconductor materials play a crucial role, which not only require good light trapping ability, but also need to have sufficient PEC activity. Metal oxides with narrow bandgap are good PEC materials. In addition to having strong chemical stability, they can convert absorbed sunlight into electron-hole pairs with redox ability, which can be used for redox reactions [5]. Tungsten trioxide (WO3) is an n-type semiconductor with a bandgap of 2.7 eV, which has advantages such as strong visible light response, moderate hole diffusion distance, and good chemical stability [6–9]. However, WO3 nanomaterials still suffer from problems such as high electron-hole recombination probability, difficulty in one-step formation on substrates and small specific surface area, which to some extent limit the application of WO3 in the field of PEC [10–13]. To overcome these problems and improve the performance of WO3, great efforts have been made, such as constructing heterojunctions [14–16], introducing defects [17,18], ion doping [19,20], loading co-catalysts [21,22], and generating plasma effects [23,24]. The performance of WO3-based photoelectrodes has been improved to some extent, but how to prepare WO3 nanomaterials with uniform morphology and larger surface area on the substrate through simple synthesis steps remains a challenge. In fact, the mismatch between WO3 and substrate materials (such as FTO) leads to a high probability of interface electron-hole recombination, which severely limits the further improvement of WO3 PEC performance [25]. In this work, tungsten mesh was used as the conductive substrate material to grow WO3 nanosheets in situ through a one-step method. The preparation process is simple and the problem of interface recombination of conventional photoelectrode is fundamentally solved. In situ growth reduces interfacial resistance, providing conditions for effective collection of photo generated electrons. The two-dimensional nanosheet structure of WO3 increases the contact area with the electrolyte, facilitating rapid injection of photogenerated holes while providing directional channels for the transport of photogenerated electrons, resulting in high durability and PEC stability of the sample [3,14]. This unique property provides a new avenue for the application of WO3 in catalysis, adsorption, and sensing fields. In addition, the high temperature resistance and corrosion resistance of tungsten mesh are extremely strong, which enhances the potential application of the photoelectrode system in practical complex environmental conditions. In addition to changing the substrate to eliminate contact interface recombination, constructing p-n heterojunctions is also an effective method to improve the PEC performance of WO3. Cuprous oxide (Cu2O) is a typical oxide semiconductor, which is widely used in photocatalysis [26], lithium-ion batteries, gas sensors and other fields due to its excellent stability and environmental friendliness [27,28]. The unmodified Cu2O has low charge separation efficiency and is not an ideal PEC material. However, combining Cu2O with customized n-type semiconductors can generate an internal electric field at the p-n junction, improving the efficiency of photogenerated electron-hole pair separation [29–31]. In this work, WO3/Cu2O p-n heterojunction structures based on tungsten mesh were constructed by a two-step process, and the Cu2O loading was controlled by adjusting the electrodeposition time. Under the optimal parameters, the current density of photoanode reached 1.47 mA cm−2 at 1.23 V vs. RHE, which is approximately three times that of WO3. After deposition of Cu2O, a p-n heterojunction was formed, which enhances the visible light absorption range of the WO3 photoelectrode and forms an internal electric field, improving its carrier separation efficiency. This implies that the p-n heterojunction is potentially promising in the prospect of PEC water decomposition. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials Hydrochloric acid (HCl, AR (36–38 %)), nitric acid ( HNO3, AR (99.5 %)) and copper sulfate hydrate (CuSO4-5H2O, AR (98 %)) were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd. Anhydrous sodium sulfate ( Na2SO4, AR (98.0 %)), anhydrous ethanol (CH3CH2OH, AR (99.7 %)), sodium hydroxide (NaOH, AR) and citric acid hydrate (CA, C6H8O7-H2O, AR) were purchased from Sinopharm Group Chemical Reagent Co. The chemicals and reagents were purchased and used without any further purification. Ultrapure water was used to prepare solutions and wash instruments and samples. 2.2 Preparation of WO3 nanosheet The 150-mesh tungsten mesh was cut into a rectangle with a width of 1 cm and a length of 3 cm to serve as the reaction substrate. After rinsing with deionized water three times, the tungsten mesh was placed in a beaker filled with sufficient anhydrous ethanol for ultrasonic cleaning for 10 min. After rinsing with deionized water and drying with nitrogen gas, two pieces of tungsten mesh were diagonally placed into a 25 ml Teflon lining. Then 9 ml of HCl and 3 ml of HNO3 were added into the inner liner, and the reaction was carried out in the reactor at 80 °C for 1 h. After cooling to room temperature, take it out, rinse it with deionized water, dry it, and put it into the muffle furnace at 500 °C to maintain 3 h, WO3 was obtained at the end of annealing. 2.3 Formation of WO3/Cu2O p-n heterojunctions The electrolyte for electrodeposition was composed of 0.1 M CuSO4-5H2O and 1 M C6H8O7-H2O, and then the pH of the solution was adjusted to 11 using 4 M NaOH. Electrodeposition was carried out in an electrochemical workstation with a three-electrode system, which Pt electrode was used as the counter electrode, Ag/AgCl (3 M KCl) electrode as the reference electrode, and WO3 as the working electrode. The electrodeposition temperature is maintained at 50 °C, and the deposition was carried out for 20 to 300 s at a potential of −0.4 V vs. Ag/AgCl. After electrodeposition, the obtained electrode samples were washed with deionized water and ethanol respectively, and then dried naturally. The prepared sample is labeled as WO3/Cu2O-x, where x represents the electrodeposition time. The preparation process of pure Cu2O photoelectrode is the same as that of WO3/Cu2O, except that tungsten mesh is used as the working electrode. 2.4 Characterize The morphology and microstructure of WO3/Cu2O heterojunctions were investigated using high-resolution scanning electron microscopy (HR-SEM, Regulus-8100 10.0 kV 8.7 mm × 50.0 SE(UL), Hitachi, Japan) and high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM, H-7800, Hitachi, Japan). The crystal structure of WO3/Cu2O nanoarrays was characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD, Cu Kα radiation, Brucker Co, Germany). The elemental composition and corresponding valence states in WO3-Cu2O-60s were studied using X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Thermo Scientific K-Alpha, USA. The light absorption properties of the WO3/Cu2O nanoarrays were investigated by UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (UV-3600, Shimadzu, Japan). 2.5 Photoelectrochemical measurements PEC performance measurements were conducted in an electrochemical station (CHI 660E, Shanghai Chenhua) with a three-electrode system. The prepared samples were used as the working electrode and its irradiated area was fixed at 0.28 cm2 with a mask. A Pt sheet and an Ag/AgCl (3M KCl) electrode were used as counter electrode and reference electrode, respectively. The three electrodes were immersed in 0.5 M Na2SO4 solution (pH = 6.5). AM 1.5 G sunlight simulator (100 mW cm−2) was used as the measurement light source. The electrochemical impedance spectra (EIS) of the electrodes were measured in the frequency range of 105–0.1 Hz to describe the carrier transport performance at the electrode/electrolyte interface. The Mott–Schottky (M–S) curves were obtained for the samples at a frequency of 1000 Hz. Incident photo-to-current conversion efficiency (IPCE) curves in the 300–800 nm range were recorded at 1.23 V vs. RHE under AM 1.5G illumination. All potentials of photoelectrodes versus Ag/AgCl are converted to potential versus RHE using the Nernst equation [32]: (1) V RHE = V Ag / Agcl + 0.197 + 0.0591 × pH The incident photo-to-current conversion efficiency can be calculated by the following equation [33]: (2) IPCE = 1240 × J photo λ × P light × 100 % J photo is the measured photocurrent density (mA cm−2), λ is the wavelength (nm) and the Plight is the corresponding power density (mW cm−2). The applied bias photon-to-current efficiency (ABPE) can be calculated by the below equation [33]: (3) ABPE = J photo × ( 1.23 − V app ) P light × 100 % J photo is the measured photocurrent density, V app is the applied bias (VRHE), and Plight is the incident light density (100 mW cm−2). The charge carrier density (Nd) can be calculated by the following equation based on the M–S plot [33]: (4) N d = ( 2 e ε 0 ε ) × ( d ( 1 C 2 ) dVs ) − 1 ε 0 is the vacuum permittivity 8.854 × 10−12 F m−1, ε is the relative permittivity 44.7 F m−1 for WO3 [34]. C is the space charge capacitance (F m−2), VS is the applied bias (V) and d (1/C2)/ d V s is the slope of the M–S curve. The C d l can be calculated to represent electrochemical active surface area (ECSA) by the following equation [32]: (5) I c = C dl × ( d φ dt ) I c is the electric double layer current density (mA cm−2), C d l is the electric double layer capacitance (F cm−2), d φ /dt is the scan rate (mV s−1) 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Formation process of WO3/Cu2O The preparation process of WO3/Cu2O heterojunction was shown in Fig. 1 . Firstly, the substrate tungsten mesh was subjected to hydrothermal reaction, and after high-temperature annealing treatment, WO3 nanosheets were obtained in situ. During this process, the following chemical reactions may occur [35]: (6) W + 6 HN O 3 + 6 HCl → W ( N O 3 ) 6 + 6 C l − + 3 H 2 O (7) W ( N O 3 ) 6 Δ → W O 3 + 6 N O 2 + 3 / 2 O 2 Secondly, Cu2O was deposited onto WO3 nanosheets using electrochemical deposition method to form heterojunctions, and the temperature needs to be maintained at 50 °C during this process. In order to better investigate the effect of Cu2O loading on PEC performance, we prepared samples with different electrodeposition times (labeled as WO3/Cu2O-20s, WO3/Cu2O-60s, and WO3/Cu2O-80s). The following chemical reactions may take place during the electrodeposition process [35]: (8) C u 2 + + e 1 − → C u 1 + (9) 2 C u 1 + + 2 O H 1 − → C u 2 O + H 2 3.2 Morphology and structure The morphology and structure of the obtained materials were characterized by high-resolution scanning electron microscopy (HR-SEM) and high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM). Compared with the untreated 150 mesh tungsten mesh in Fig. 2 a, it can be clearly seen from Fig. 2b, c that WO3 grows in situ on the tungsten mesh after hydrothermal treatment [30]. Under high magnification field of view, it can be observed that the obtained WO3 has a smooth nanosheet structure with an average thickness of about 150 nm (Figs. 2d and S1). After modification with Cu2O, there was no significant change in the morphology of WO3 nanosheets (Fig. 2e), only an increase in the thickness of the nanosheets. As shown in Fig. 2e, after 60 s of electrodeposition of Cu2O, the thickness of WO3 nanosheets increased to 160 nm. In addition, it can be seen that after modification small particles adhere to the surface of the nanosheets. According to the selected EDS analysis (Fig. S2), the content of Cu in these small particles is significantly higher than that in the nanosheet region, which may be caused by the aggregation of Cu2O on the surface of WO3 during the electrodeposition process. Similar morphological changes were also observed on photoelectrodes with electrodeposition times of 20 s and 80 s. The aggregation of Cu2O on the surface of WO3 can be further confirmed by TEM characterization, as shown in Fig. S3. At low resolution, small particles can be seen attached to the edges of WO3 nanosheets (Fig. S3a). As shown in Figs. 2f and S3b, c, clear lattice spacing of 0.248 nm corresponded to the (111) plane of Cu2O [35], and 0.371 nm was assigned to the (200) plane of WO3 [35–37]. The clear interface between WO3 and Cu2O in HR-TEM further confirms the successful formation of a p-n heterojunction between the two [38,39]. Fig. 2g shows the elemental mapping of the selected area, and the two-dimensional structure of the composite material is clearly visible. The W, Cu, and O elements are uniformly dispersed in the field of view, indicating successful growth of Cu2O on the WO3 surface. X-ray diffraction was used to characterize the crystal structure of the obtained WO3 and WO3/Cu2O heterojunction electrodes. As shown in Fig. 3 a, the diffraction peaks at 40.41° and 73.32° correspond to (110) and (221) crystal planes of the substrate tungsten network, respectively. Compared with the standard PDF card (NO.05-0363), it can be clearly seen that the diffraction peaks located at 23.63°, 34.23°, 50.07° and 58.35° correspond to the (020), (220), (140) and (331) crystal planes of WO3, respectively [35]. The introduction of Cu2O did not change the crystallinity of WO3, and there was no obvious diffraction peaks related to Cu2O detected in the spectrum due to the low loading of Cu2O [26]. However, in addition to the above morphological observation, subsequent characterization can further prove the successful modification of Cu2O. Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopic analysis can identify the structure and chemical bonding of the molecule to determine the presence of species. As shown in Fig. 3b, the vibration peaks located at 743 cm−1 and 815 cm−1 are attributed to the WO chemical bonding in the substrate WO3 [40]. After Cu2O modification, a new characteristic peak appeared at 3380 cm−1, which is attributed to CuO bonding, confirming the attachment of Cu2O on the surface of WO3 [40]. In order to further investigate the elemental composition and corresponding valence states, XPS characterization was performed on the electrode samples. The full XPS spectra of WO3 and WO3/Cu2O-60s samples are shown in Fig. 4 a, confirming the simultaneous existence of W, O and Cu after modification [40]. As Fig. 4b shown, in the high-resolution spectrum of W 4f, the characteristic peaks located at 35.38 eV and 37.58 eV correspond to W 4f7/2 and W 4f5/2, respectively [41]. The double-peak heavy state can be clearly observed, which indicates that W exists in the form of +6 valance [42]. Compared with the W 4f binding energy of WO3, the W 4f of WO3/Cu2O-60s shifted to a lower binding energy, which may be due to the generation of oxygen vacancies results in increase of electron density around the W atoms [43]. No obvious low valence state characteristic peaks of W were observed, suggesting that the WO3 was not reduced during the electrodeposition process [44,45]. As shown in Fig. 4c, the Cu 2p3/2 and Cu 2p1/2 peaks in the Cu 2p spectra can be resolved at the binding energies of 932.38 eV, 935.08 eV, and 951.98, 954.98 eV, respectively. This indicates that Cu is mainly in the Cu+ chemical state [46–48]. Furthermore, due to the open 3d9 shell layer of Cu2+, an oscillating satellite peak appeared at 943.28 eV. This implies that the surface of Cu2O was slightly oxidized in air under ambient conditions [49,50]. As shown in Fig. 4d, the O 1s high-resolution spectrum consists of three characteristic peaks at 530.08 eV, 532.08 eV and 533.28 eV, representing lattice oxygen (Olatt), oxygen vacancies (Ov) and surface adsorbed oxygen (Oads), respectively [40]. It can be seen from Fig. 4d that there was no significant change in the binding energy of O 1s. The increase in Ov (34.2 % to 36.1 %) precisely explains the shift in the binding energy of W 4f mentioned above [51–53]. The XPS results further proved the successful modification of Cu2O [54]. 3.3 Characterization of energy band structure The UV visible absorption spectra of the photoanodes are shown in Figs. 5 a and S4a. WO3 exhibits a typical absorption edge around 450 nm, while Cu2O exhibits an absorption edge around 600 nm, which were all consistent with similar literature reports [33,55]. After modification, the introduction of narrow bandgap Cu2O enhances the light absorption performance of the photoanodes between 450 nm and 550 nm (Fig. 5b). Furthermore, the bandgap value of the photoanode can be calculated using absorption spectroscopy and the following formula [56,57]: (10) α h v = A ( h v − E g ) n where A is a constant and n is equal to =1/2 or 2 for allowed direct or indirect transitions respectively, and according to literature WO3 is an indirect semiconductor, and Cu2O is a direct semiconductor [57,58]. The tauc diagrams related to bandgap value obtained through conversion were shown in Fig.S4b and c. It can be concluded that the band gaps of the WO3 and Cu2O were 2.87 eV and 1.83 eV, respectively [43]. The Mott–Schottky curves of WO3, WO3/Cu2O-60s photoanodes and Cu2O were shown in Figs. 5c, d and S4d. A positive slope indicates that WO3 and WO3/Cu2O-60s photoanodes are n-type semiconductors, while a negative slope indicates that Cu2O prepared by electrodeposition is a p-type semiconductor (Fig. 5d). The lower the slope, the higher the carrier density [33]. From Figs. 5c, S4d, it can be seen that the slope of the WO3/Cu2O-60s photoanode is significantly smaller than that of WO3, indicating that the modification has increased the carrier concentration of the system. However, as the deposition time of Cu2O increases, the slope becomes larger, and the carrier concentration in the heterojunction system tends to decrease. This may be caused by excessive deposition causing Cu2O aggregation, increasing the probability of electron-hole recombination and decreasing the charge separation efficiency [34]. For better illustration, the carrier concentration (Nd) can be calculated using Eq. (4), and the Nd for WO3 and WO3/Cu2O-60 s Nd are 5.5 × 1021 cm−3 and 9.0 × 1021 cm−3, respectively. The construction of heterojunction increases the carrier concentration of the system. The flat band potential of the photoanode can be obtained from the Mott–Schottky curve, which is the interception of the tangent line on the x-axis [59]. From Figs. 5c, S4d, it can be seen that the flat band potentials of WO3 and WO3/Cu2O-60s are 0.97 and 0.18 V vs. RHE, respectively. The negative shift of flat band potential implies band bending, indicating that modification is beneficial for charge separation and transfer [33]. The conduction band CB potential of the photoanode is usually negative by 0.2 V compared to the flat band potential, so it can be inferred that the CB of WO3 and WO3/Cu2O-60s are located at 0.77 eV and −0.02 eV, respectively [60]. Combined with the calculated bandgap value, the bandgap structure diagram was drawn before and after modification, as shown in Fig. 5e. Under illumination, the WO3 photoanode is activated to generate electron-hole pairs, and photogenerated electrons transition to the conduction band (CB) and aggregate (Fig. 5e-A). Due to the large number of internal defects causing bulk recombination (Jb,rec) and slow surface reaction kinetics (Kct), the PEC performance of WO3 photoelectrodes is limited [59]. After constructing the WO3/Cu2O heterojunction (Fig. 5e-B), the photogenerated holes on the valence band (VB) of WO3 can be transferred to the VB of Cu2O under the driving of the built-in electric field. At the same time, electrons on the CB of Cu2O are injected into the CB of WO3, forming charge separation in space, accelerating the reaction kinetics (Kct), and improving its PEC performance. In order to construct a WO3/Cu2O photoelectrode system with optimal performance, the effects of different electrodeposition time on PEC performance of WO3/Cu2O photoelectrode system were studied (Fig. S6). As shown in Fig. 6 a, the Cu2O modified photoanodes exhibit a significant enhancement of photoelectric response. Especially when the deposition time is 60 s, the photocurrent density of the WO3/Cu2O heterojunction reaches its maximum value of 1.47 mA cm−2 at 1.23 V vs. RHE, which is three times that of the original WO3 (0.45 mA cm−2). As the electrodeposition time further increased to 80 s, the photocurrent showed a decreasing trend, which may be related to excessive Cu2O deposition restricting carrier conduction. This can be confirmed by subsequent electrochemical impedance spectroscopy tests. Fig. 6b shows the amperometric I-t curves of different photoanodes at 1.23 V vs. RHE. It is clear that these photoanodes exhibit sensitive responses during the light on/off conversion process, demonstrating rapid charge separation efficiency, and the photocurrent values are consistent with the LSV results. The improvement of performance and electron-hole separation efficiency by Cu2O modification can also be confirmed from the potential step I-t curve in Fig. 6c. At the potential of 0.8 V vs. RHE, WO3 shows almost no response, which is related to its slow reaction dynamics [33]. Cu2O modification improved the efficiency of electron-hole separation, thereby reducing overpotential, resulting in a significant response step value of the modified electrode system at 0.8 V vs. RHE. As the potential increases, the step values of Cu2O modified photoanodes gradually increase, and WO3/Cu2O-60s has the best PEC performance. The corresponding LSV curves can be used to derive the applied bias photon current efficiency (ABPE) according to formula (3) in experimental section, which is used to describe the changes in the light conversion efficiency of the photoanodes before and after Cu2O modification. The results in Fig. 6d confirm that the PEC performance of the modified electrodes has been significantly improved. From the Fig., it can be seen that the WO3/Cu2O-60s photoanode has the highest ABPE value, which reaches 1.37 % at 0.71 V vs. RHE. The corresponding values for WO3, WO3/Cu2O-20s and WO3/Cu2O-80s are 0.58 %, 0.52 % and 0.57 %, respectively. As shown in Fig. 6e, the incident photon-to-current conversion efficiency (IPCE) results further confirm the excellent modification performance [61]. Within the testing wavelength range of 310–600 nm, the WO3/Cu2O-60s photoanode has the highest IPCE values, reaching a maximum of 30 % at 440 nm, which is twice times that of pure WO3. The test results of ABPE and IPCE demonstrate that the construction of built-in electric fields in heterojunctions promotes effective separation of photogenerated electron-hole pairs. In order to further study the effect of Cu2O modification on the charge transfer performance of the electrode system, the photocurrent density of the photoelectrode was measured by using a 1 M sodium sulfite (Na2SO3) solution as hole trapping agent. The charge injection efficiency (ηin) can be obtained according to formula (11): (11) η in = J Photocurrent / J N a 2 S O 3 in which, J Photocurrent (mA cm−2) was the photocurrent density in 0.5 M Na2SO4 electrolyte and J N a 2 S O 3 (mA cm−2) was the photocurrent density in 1 M sodium sulfite solution. As shown in Figs. 7 a and S7, the ηin of all WO3/Cu2O photoanode are higher than that of the bare WO3 over the entire potential range. The maximum values for WO3 and WO3/Cu2O-60s are 13 % and 38.5 %, respectively, indicating an improvement in the charge injection capability at the electrode/electrolyte interface [62,63]. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) testing was an effective method to study the capacitance and resistance of electrode materials, which can further characterize the charge separation of different electrode systems. The larger the semicircle of EIS curve, the greater the charge transfer resistance [64,65]. As shown in Fig. 7a, compared to the original WO3, the arc radius of all electrodes modified with Cu2O decreases, indicating a decrease in charge transfer resistance. As the deposition time increases, the arc radius of EIS first decreases and then increases. The WO3/Cu2O-60s has the smallest arc radius, indicating the smallest charge transfer resistance, which is more favorable for improving the charge transfer ability of the photoelectrode [64]. Within the testing frequency range, the EIS spectra of the four electrodes can be fitted into semicircles of different diameters, with the equivalent circuit model shown in Fig. 7b. By fitting the EIS curve with an equivalent circuit, the series resistance (Rs) and the interfacial charge transfer resistance (Rct) can be obtained [66]. The calculated values of Rs and Rct for the four samples are shown in Table S1. The WO3/Cu2O-60s (Rct, 3068 Ω) photoanode resistance curve has the smallest arc radius. Compared to WO3 (Rct, 15233 Ω), the charge transfer resistance is lower. This indicates that the WO3/Cu2O p-n heterojunction can reduce charge transfer resistance and accelerate carriers’ diffusion kinetics, thereby improving PEC performance [67]. This result is highly consistent with the observation results (Fig. 7a) [68]. The electrochemical active surface area (ECSA) reflects the potential oxidation active site, and its value directly affects the PEC performance of the photoanode [59,69]. In order to investigate the effect of scanning rate on the peak potential and peak current of the electrode surface, and to better understand the kinetics and behavior of electrochemical reactions on Cu2O modified electrodes [41], CV test was conducted on different photoanode in the range of 0.1–0.3 V vs. Ag/AgCl potential (Fig. 8 a–d). With the scanning speed as the horizontal coordinate and the CV current difference at 0.2 V potential as the vertical coordinate, the slope of the curve reflects the size of electrochemical double-layer capacitance (Cdl) of photoanode (Fig. 8e), which is positively correlated with the electrochemically active surface area (ESCA) [68]. As shown in Fig. 8e, compared to the original WO3, the Cdl values of WO3/Cu2O-20s and WO3/Cu2O-60s are higher than that of WO3, indicating an improvement in ECSA. While the Cdl value of WO3/Cu2O-80s is lower than that of WO3, which indicates that the Cdl value of the composite electrode increases after the formation of a P-N heterojunction between WO3 and Cu2O, the electrodeposited content should be controlled. Excessive deposition of Cu2O will bias the P-type semiconductors and reduce their Cdl values [70]. Therefore, it is feasible to improve its PEC performance by proper deposition of Cu2O. Fig. 8f shows the stability test of the photoanode under continuous illumination. The photocurrent of the original WO3 continued to decrease and only maintained about 40 % of the initial value after two hours continuous illumination. After Cu2O modification, the stability of WO3/Cu2O was significantly improved. As shown in Fig. 8f, it remained at 88 % of the initial value after two hours of stability testing. The built-in electric field formed by the construction of the WO3/Cu2O heterojunction system enhances the transfer efficiency of photogenerated carriers and suppresses the recombination probability of electron-hole pairs [59]. The two-dimensional nanosheet structure of WO3 increases the contact area with the electrolyte, facilitating rapid injection of photogenerated holes while providing directional channels for the transport of photogenerated electrons, resulting in high durability and PEC stability of the sample [60]. Indicating that the modification brought excellent stability and strong repeatability [71,72]. A comparison for the performance of WO3-based photoanodes and similar photoanodes reported in the literature was shown in Table S2. These records demonstrate the excellent performance of our WO3/Cu2O photoanode. Fig. 9 shows the schematic diagram of WO3/Cu2O heterojunction photoanode for water oxidation. In the p-n heterojunction composite structure, WO3 and Cu2O are excited under light irradiation to generate electron-hole pairs, respectively. The appropriate gradient bandgap mechanism promotes the spatial separation of electron hole pairs. Under the action of the built-in electric, photogenerated electrons transfer from the CB of Cu2O (0.18 eV) to the CB of WO3 (0.97 eV) and finally reach the counter electrode through the external circuit to undergo a reduction reaction and produce hydrogen. Correspondingly, the photo-generated holes transfer from the valence band of WO3 (2.87 eV) to the valence band of Cu2O (2.69 eV) and ultimately arrive at the electrode electrolyte interface for water oxidation reaction. The construction of WO3/Cu2O heterojunction promotes the effective separation of electrons and holes, thereby improving the efficiency of the photocurrent conversion process. 4 Conclusion In summary, the WO3/Cu2O p-n heterojunction photoelectrode system was successfully constructed through a two-step approach in this work. Compared with the original WO3, this system exhibits outstanding PEC response and photochemical stability. The in-situ growth of WO3 on tungsten mesh reduces the interfacial contact resistance, and the regular nanosheet morphology provides a large specific surface area for oxidation reactions. The designed and prepared WO3/Cu2O heterojunction structure improves the slow charge transport dynamics of WO3 by forming built-in electric field, achieving efficient light absorption and charge separation. This work provides a new strategy for optimizing and modifying photoelectrodes. CRediT authorship contribution statement Zilong Zhang: Writing – original draft, Investigation, Formal analysis. coredata.dc:description: Seeking and constructing a suitable p-n heterojunction photoelectrode system is crucial for improving the efficiency of photogenerated electron-hole separation. Herein, the WO3/Cu2O heterostructure was successfully constructed on tungsten mesh using a two-step method. The photoelectrochemical (PEC) properties of the photoanodes loaded with different amounts of Cu2O were investigated by controlling the electrodeposition time. The photocurrent density of the heterojunction with the 60 s electrodeposition time is the highest, reaching 1.47 mA cm−2 at 1.23 V vs. RHE, which is three times that of WO3 nanosheets (0.45 mA cm−2) grown in situ on tungsten mesh. The improved PEC performance is attributed to the wider light absorption spectrum, enhanced photogenerated carrier transfer efficiency and suppressed electron-hole recombination probability. This study indicates that the WO3/Cu2O heterojunction structure grown and constructed in-situ on tungsten mesh has exciting potential for application in efficiency PEC water separation devices. Moreover, it also provides a feasible approach for designing heterostructure systems adapted to complex environments on different substrates to improve PEC efficiency.
